archimate:BusinessObject.name: Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA)
archimate:BusinessObject.documentation:
Short about purpose and target group The purpose of the DORA regulation is to contribute to increased digital operational resilience within the EU's financial sector and its critical ICT (information and communication-related) services. For example, DORA will apply to organizations that provide: audit services, insurance services, banking and financial services, crypto services, securities services and third party ICT service providers.
The most important commitments for Sweden Provisions on ICT risk management, reporting and management of ICT-related incidents, ICT security testing, ICT third-party risk management and information sharing. Penalty fees will be based on the severity of the non-compliance. In the case of IT third-party providers, a penalty fee will be issued on a daily basis until the operator fixes the problem. In some cases, the penalty can be up to 1% of the business's global turnover.
The most important opportunities for Sweden, including the impact on security
DORA aims to further increase the financial sector's IT security and, thereby, its resilience to digital disruption and cyber risks.
The regulations will drive the financial sector to identify resilience for critical functions and underlying processes. At the same time, the financial sector is of great importance to the entire society both in peacetime and during high alert. Financial services is one of the 10 designated preparedness sectors6 and the regulation will make an important contribution to the robustness, resilience and redundancy of the sector in the digital domain. This contributes to increased capability both with regard to Sweden's crisis preparedness and total defence.
Time perspective (when it starts to apply)
The new regulation will also mean closer cooperation within Europe and between suppliers, which strengthens common European security on the market. ESA (European Supervisory Authorities) will, among other things, have new areas of responsibility and will have to take on greater responsibility within the EU, e.g. vis-a-vis ICT third-party suppliers.
Time perspective (when it starts to apply)
The regulation went into effect on January 16, 2023. After that, financial entities have twentyfour months to comply with DORA. On January 17, 2025, the regulation begins to be applied.
